snippet: The Supreme Court found a “ministerial exception” to job discrimination laws, saying religious groups must be free to choose leaders without government interference.
abstract: Supreme Court for the first time recognizes a 'ministerial exception' to employment discrimination laws, saying that churches and other religious groups must be free to choose and dismiss their leaders without government interference; decision gives only limited guidance about how courts should decide who counts as a minister.

byline.contributor: Laurie Goodstein contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court found a “ministerial exception” to job discrimination laws, saying religious groups must be free to choose leaders without government interference.

headline.seo: Justices Recognize ‘Ministerial Exception’ to Job Bias Laws
headline.main: Religious Groups Given ‘Exception’ to Work Bias Law
headline.print_headline: Religious Groups Given ‘Exception’ To Work Bias Law
